Authors:
Mohammad Ziaur Rahman, Seiji Uematsu, Haruhisa Suga, koji
Kageyama
Title:
Two varieties, Phytophthora nagaii var. nagaii and P. nagaii
var. fragariaefolia, of a new Phytophthora species causing serious
diseases of rose and strawberry, respectively, in Japan
Keywords:
Fast growing. Phytophthora. Phylogeny. Rose.
Strawberry.
Abstract:
A new disease of rose was noticed in Chiba district of
Japan in 1968 and the pathogen was primarily identified as Phytophthora
megasperma based on morphological characteristics. Similar Phytophthora
species was isolated again from Chiba, Kanagawa and Shizuoka districts,
until 2004. P. megasperma is a complex species and some new species have
been segregated from this complex species. On the other hand, several
isolates were recovered recently from leaf, petiole, runner and crown
rot of strawberry in Hokkaido in 2005 and morphologically and
phylogenetically considered to be a new species. All the isolates were
re-examined based on morphological study and multi-locus phylogenetic
analyses including rDNA ITS regions, rDNA LSU, translation elongation
factor 1-Î±, Î²-tubulin and coxI genes. In the morphological study, both
rose and strawberry isolates showed mostly similar characteristics and
significantly differed from P. megasperma sensu stricto and other
related Phytophthora species by its external proliferation,
characteristic funnel shaped oogonia, predominantly paragynous and
intercalary antheridia and fast growth, 10.5 mm/day at the optimum
temperature, 28ÂºC. In the multi-locus phylogenetic tree, they formed
distinct monophyletic group in clade 7 with strong bootstrap support,
although there are some differences in the position of the rose and
strawberry isolates. The results indicate that the rose and strawberry
isolates will be the same species consisting of two varieties and
designated here as Phytophthora nagaii var. nagaii and P. nagaii var.
fragariaefolia.
